Western Digital (WDC) on Wednesday announced what it called a "breakthrough" innovation that should enable the development of a disk drive able to store 40 terabytes of data and beyond by 2025.The new Western Digital technology was announced at the company's headquarters in Silicon Valley and included a demonstration of what it called "the world's first microwave-assisted magnetic recording," known as MAMR.In the press release announcing the new technology, Western Digital quoted IDC analyst John Rydning as saying "Western Digital's demonstration of MAMR technology is a significant breakthrough for the hard-disk-drive industry."At the heart of the company's breakthrough, said Western Digital, is the "spin torque oscillator" used to generate a microwave field that increases the ability to record data at ultrahigh density.IBD'S TAKE: Read IBD's The Big Picture column each day to stay on top of the market direction, a key indicator that lets you know when you can be aggressive and when you should move to the sidelines.Western Digital recently set a record for the highest-capacity disk drive, which holds 14 terabytes, designed for cloud data centers. Western Digital is the largest provider of disk drives, followed by Seagate Technology (STX). Western Digital is also a major supplier of memory chips.Western Digital expects to begin shipping disk drives in 2019 "for use in data centers that support Big Data applications across a full range of industries."Western Digital shares dipped 0.5% to close at 85.62 on the stock market today.RELATED:Western Digital Escalates Tussle With Toshiba Over Chip Plant

Western Digital (WDC) shares fell Wednesday following news that Toshiba will sell a prized chip unit to a rival group led by Bain Capital and Korea-based SK Hynix.XThe deal, announced by Toshiba late Tuesday, is a blow to Western Digital, which spent months negotiating and wrangling with Toshiba to acquire the specialized unit that makes memory chips.The Bain Capital group reportedly bid $19 billion for the business, above the reported bid of $18.2 billion by the Western Digital group, which included private equity firm KKR. Apple (AAPL) is said to be involved with the Bain Capital group.Western Digital stock fell 3.4% to close at 85.74 on the stock market today.Toshiba said it entered a memorandum of understanding with the Bain group and hopes to enter a final decision by the end of this month. Two Japanese newspapers had previously reported that Western Digital won the bidding.The Toshiba unit makes a popular computer memory chip known as Nand flash, which is used in a wide variety of consumer electronics and in chip-based data storage systems. Western Digital acquired a stake in the business, resulting from its $15.8 billion SanDisk acquisition.Toshiba is under heavy pressure to sell the chip unit, in order to cover massive losses from its nuclear division and avoid having its stock delisted from Japan's stock exchanges.Western Digital has worked to acquire the Toshiba unit to fortify its strong and growing presence in the memory-chip market — chips that are used broadly in smartphones, memory cards, USB drives, solid-state drives, digital cameras and other devices. In addition to being a competitive force in chips, Western Digital is also the world's largest manufacturer of disk drives, competing against Seagate Technology (STX)Western Digital has fought legal battles against Toshiba to prevent any deal that did not have its consent, in order to preserve intellectual property and prevent the chip unit from falling into the hands of competitors. That includes Broadcom (AVGO), which reportedly bid on the unit. Broadcom is a leading manufacturer of chips used in wireless and broadband communication.IBD'S TAKE: Western Digital holds a strong IBD Composite Rating of 95 out of a possible 99. There are plenty of places on Investors.com to research and find top stocks, but when you're looking to get a broader idea on top tech stocks, IBD's Tech Leaders feature is worth reviewing.The Bain Capital/SK Hynix group had previously been selected by Toshiba as the winning bidder. That deal collapsed under heavy legal pressure by Western Digital.Western Digital implied it might continue legal action, in a statement issued late Tuesday."It is surprising that Toshiba would continue to pursue a transaction with a consortium led by Korea-based SK Hynix and Bain Capital Japan without SanDisk's consent," Western Digital said in a prepared statement. "The language in the relevant joint venture agreements is unambiguous, and multiple courts have ruled in favor of protecting SanDisk's contractual rights. We remain confident in our ability to protect our joint venture interests and consent rights."It said "arbitration requests" are on file and continue to move forward in the ICC International Court of Arbitration.The other group bidding for the unit is a consortium led by manufacturing giant Foxconn that includes Apple.RELATED:Toshiba Agrees To Talk With Western Digital Over Disputed Chip DealWestern Digital Seeks To Block Toshiba Chip Sale Via Arbitration

The Nasdaq charged to another new high at Thursday's open, up 0.3%, while the S&P 500 added 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average battled to remain positive as General Electric (GE) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH) pulled down hard in early trade.XMicrosoft (MSFT) easily led the Dow, up 1% after Canaccord Genuity upgraded the stock to buy, from hold. Microsoft has been attempting to muster the volume support necessary to break clear of a 74.52 flat base buy point.Apple (AAPL) jumped 1%, while all four of the FANG stocks posted strong early gains. Netflix (NFLX) led with a 1.5% gain. The stock posted a soled 3% advance on Wednesday, lifting shares to within 3% of a 190.05 buy point.Crane maker Manitowoc (MTW) hoisted a 8% opening advance. Auto racecourse operator International Speedway (ISCA) rolled out a 4% gain.Biotech drugmaker Biogen (BIIB) popped 3%. Morgan Stanley upgraded the stock to overweight, from equal weight and raised its price target to 375, from 311. The jump put shares in a buy range on a rebound, in a test of support at its 10-week moving average.Celgene (CELG) dropped 3%, after Morgan Stanley trimmed its rating to underweight, from equal weight. The IBD 50 stock ended Wednesday just beyond buy range, after clearing a 139.10 buy point Sept. 1.Constellation Brands (STX) spiked 4% in early action, after its fiscal second quarter earnings soared past consensus targets. Revenue was also better than expected, with sales of its beer brands driving the beat. Shares ended Wednesday in a buy range, above a 199.99 buy point in a seven-week flat base.Shopify (SHOP) dived 2% at the start of the session. The maker of online platforms for small businesses plunged 11% in massive trade Wednesday, after a negative report from short-seller Citron.  The move pierced the stock's 10-week moving average, triggering a sell signal.The market receives a healthy dose of economic news and Federal Reserve Commentary today, but investors are likely to limit their response until the Labor Department's September payrolls report rolls out Friday.The number of layoffs announced by U.S. employers dropped 4% from August to September, to 32,346, according to consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas.  The number was 27% below year-ago levels, and brought total layoffs during the third quarter to 94,478, down 6% from the second quarter and 23% lower than last year's third quarter.First-time unemployment claims dropped to 260,000 in the week ended Sept. 30, the Labor Department reported, down from 272,000 in the prior week and below consensus views for 265,000 new claims. Continuing claims increased slightly to 1.938 million.The U.S. trade deficit narrowed slightly in August, to $42.4 billion, according to Commerce Department estimates. That was down from $43.6 billion in July and slightly better than estimates for $42.5 billion.August factory orders numbers are also due from the Commerce Department at 10 a.m. ET.Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell and Fed Bank Presidents John Williams and Patrick Harker are all scheduled to speak at separate conferences with starting times set between 9:10 a.m. and 9:30 a.m. ET.RELATED:Nasdaq, S&P 500 Up 7 Days In A Row; More Important, This Is HappeningWatch Apple, FANG Stocks, But Don't Ignore This Hottest GroupStocks Up, Apple Basing; Why Investors Should Not Sell Shopify ShortShopify Falls After Short-Seller Citron Criticizes Marketing ModelIBD Investor Research Tools Getting Started With IBD

Seagate Technology (STX) was downgraded and had its price target cut by a Wall Street analyst following a review of market conditions that raised red flags.XFBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi on Monday downgraded Seagate to sector perform from outperform and cut his price target to 32 from 40.Seagate shares fell 3.3% to close at 30.95 on the stock market today.Seagate competes primarily with Western Digital (WDC) in the disk drive market. Western Digital also has a large business in chip-based storage technology. Western Digital shares were up 0.4%, near 87.38.The Seagate downgrade follows comments from disk-drive component suppliers that include Broadcom (AVGO) and Marvell Technologies (MRVL), suggesting tough times ahead in disk drives.In its Aug. 24 quarterly earnings call, Broadcom said strong growth in its disk drive business for enterprise customers currently is not sustainable and expects a sharp decline in demand, "driven by the start of an anticipated correction in the disk drive market," Seyrafi wrote in a note to clients. Enterprise business customers accounted for 37% of Seagate sales and a high percentage of its profits in the last quarter.Marvell also made comments on its quarterly earnings conference call on Aug. 24 that presented a "cautious view of disk drive demand in the near-term," wrote Seyrafi. Marvell said that there were some inventory issues and factory transitions with a few major customers. Disk drive inventories are also above average, which raises concerns about pricing, said Seyrafi.IBD'S TAKE: With thousands of publicly-traded companies to choose from, how can you quickly find the best stocks to buy right now? A good starting point is to regularly review screens that highlight the top-rated equities.Seyrafi also said industry trends favor Micron Technology (MU), a leading provider of DRAM chips uses in chip-based storage systems."We believe that current consensus estimates for Seagate are too high and need to be lowered," Seyrafi wrote. "We believe that investors should consider moving out of Seagate and into Micron." He said Micron is benefiting from healthy demand for the rise in chip-based storage systems, "which are increasingly displacing disk drives."On Monday, Seyrafi initiated coverage of Micron with an outperform rating and price target of 45.He said Micron "is a prime beneficiary of the tremendous amount of consolidation in the DRAM space over the past 10 years," as the top-three DRAM suppliers — Micron, Samsung, and SK Hynix, have grown their combined DRAM revenue share to 95% from less than 60% in 2007.Micron shares jumped 3.3% to close at 33.44.Western Digital reported strong quarterly results in late July that beat on the bottom line, while Seagate reported quarterly results that missed expectations, causing shares to tumble.RELATED:Western Digital Close To Acquiring Toshiba Chip Unit After Tough Fight

Stocks took incremental gains at Tuesday's starting bell, lifting the Dow industrials to yet another fresh high ahead of Wednesday's Fed policy announcement.XThe Dow Jones industrial average held a 0.1% gain, as the S&P 500 faded to a fractional advance. The Nasdaq Composite dipped to narrow losses as Western Digital (WDC), Seagate Technology (STX) and Tesla (TSLA) all posted early declines.The Federal Open Market Committee today begins its two-day meeting in Washington, D.C., with a policy announcement and press conference with Fed Chair Janet Yellen scheduled for Wednesday afternoon. Investors have largely been positioning for the Fed to begin winding down the $4.5 billion balance sheet it amassed in propping up the U.S. economy during the financial crisis.Chevron (CVX) and Procter & Gamble (PG) each jumped 0.5% to lead the Dow in early action. Nike (NKE) dived 1.8%, the Dow's hardest pre-market hit, after Susquehanna downgraded the stock to neutral from positive.IBD'S TAKE: Finding early stage, top-flight stocks is only part of the investing game. Knowing when to buy, and when to sell are just as important. IBD's CAN SLIM-based investment program tutors you through the start up stages, and provides an arsenal of powerful tools as you progress.Apple (AAPL) advanced 0.2%, despite some negative news about iPhone 8 demand. Morgan Stanley maintained the stock's overweight rating with a 194 price target.Facebook (FB)  led the FANG stock group with a 0.7% gain. The stock is trading just below a 175.59 buy point in a very tight, flat base.Tesla shed nearly 2% at the open after Jefferies initiated coverage on the stock with an underperform rating and a price target of 280 —  26% below its current level.Among IBD 50 stocks, organic LED maker Universal Display (OLED) narrowed to a 3% gain after popping 5% at the stat of trade. The Apple supplier is working on a fifth straight weekly gain, and extended above a double-bottom buy point at 127.88.Housing starts rose more than expected in August, to an annualized pace of 1.18 million, the Commerce Department reported, while boosting its July estimate to 1.19 million, from 1.155 million. Economists had projected a gain to a pace of 1.173 million for August.Housing permits rose to 1.3 million, up from an initial July estimate of 1.223 million. The July number was revised upward to 1.23 million. Economist had expected a slight slowdown, to a rate of 1.22 million permits issued for August.The U.S. current account balance, the difference between savings and investment, widened to -$123.1 billion in the second quarter, vs. a first-quarter tally of -$116.8 billion, according to Commerce Department data. The first quarter number was revised downward to -$113.5 billion. Consensus views had projected the second-quarter balance at -$115.1 billion.Import and export prices both increased 0.6% in August, according to Labor Department estimates. For imports, that reversed the 0.1% July decline and outpaced consensus views for a 0.4% gain. Minus oil, import prices rose 0.3%. For exports, the gain accelerated July's 0.4% advance and was far above expectations for a slowdown to 0.2% growth.Japan's market opened after a holiday weekend with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 jumping nearly 2%, chalking up a two-year closing high as it plays some catch-up to U.S. and European markets. Stocks were boosted by a weakening yen and by speculation that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may call a snap election.Japan's optimism did not transmit to global markets. Benchmarks in China posted modest losses Tuesday. Stocks in Europe were narrowly mixed near midday: London's FTSE 100 traded up 0.3%, the CAC-40 in Paris showed a 0.1% gain and Frankfurt's DAX dipped 0.1%.After the close, Adobe Systems (ADBE), Bed, Bath & Beyond (BBBY) and FedEx (FDX) are among the names scheduled to report.RELATED: Semiconductor Equipment Stocks Shift Into High GearApple iPhone 8 Demand Isn't Looking So Hit, Signs ShowGetting Started With IBDFollow The Market: Stock Market TodayUnderstand The Market: The Big Picture

A lengthy and contentious battle may soon come to a close, as a second Japanese newspaper has reported that a group led by Western Digital (WDC) won the bidding for a Toshiba memory-chip unit, for about $18.2 billion.A win by Western Digital would fortify its strong and growing presence in the memory-chip market — chips that are used broadly in smartphones, memory cards, USB drives, solid-state drives, digital cameras and other devices. In addition to being a competitive force in chips, Western Digital is also the world's largest manufacturer of disk drives, competing against Seagate Technology (STX).Toshiba denied the report on Tuesday by Japan media group Nikkan Kogyo that said Western Digital won the bidding process. Reuters is reporting that Toshiba now favors a group led by SK Hynix and Bain Capital Japan to buy its prized semiconductor business, after failing to bridge key gaps with Western Digital.Western Digital shares were up 1.6% to 88.78 in the stock market today.Toshiba is under heavy pressure to sell the chip unit, in order to cover massive losses from its nuclear division and avoid having its stock delisted from Japan's stock exchanges. Toshiba also denied an earlier report from Asahi Shimbun, a widely respected newspaper in Japan, that also said Western Digital had won the bidding process. Western Digital has not commented on the reports.Western Digital gained a stake in the Toshiba unit as a result of its $15.8 billion SanDisk acquisition. Western Digital has fought legal battles against Toshiba to prevent any deal that did not have its consent, in order to preserve intellectual property, among other reasons.IBD'S TAKE: Western Digital holds a strong IBD Composite Rating of 94 out of a possible 99, and recently moved above its 50-day moving average, which can be a positive sign. There are plenty of places on Investors.com to research and find top stocks, but when you're looking to get a broader idea on top tech stocks, IBD's Tech Leaders feature is worth reviewing.The Western Digital group includes private equity firm KKR, a public/private Japanese group called Innovation Network, and the Development Bank of Japan.Apple (AAPL) is said to be involved with the SK Hynix and Bain Capital  group.The other group bidding for the unit is a consortium led by manufacturing giant Foxconn that includes Apple.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani in a report to clients late Monday said he thinks Western Digital will end up with a minority stake in the unit, with its Japanese partners holding a minority position."We think the outcome is a positive for Western Digital," Daryanani wrote.The Toshiba unit would boost Western Digital's access to a large and growing category of memory chips called NAND flash and also prevent a "significantly worse scenario" of the unit going to competitors, Daryanani wrote. NAND flash consumption has exploded over the last 5 years.Daryanani has an outperform rating on Western Digital and a price target of 115.RELATED:Toshiba Agrees To Talk With Western Digital Over Disputed Chip DealWestern Digital Seeks To Block Toshiba Chip Sale Via Arbitration

Americans want smarter devices, homes, factories and cities, so STMicroelectronics (STM) has remade itself to deliver the smarts.One of Europe's largest semiconductor companies, STMicro is growing with red-hot demand for the chips needed for intelligent devices. Some on Wall Street seem convinced the outlook is promising for the venerable, 30-year-old Swiss firm whose stock struggled for more than a decade and a half following the dot-com boom and bust."The outlook for 2018 is pretty much a historical high," Tristan Gerra, a semiconductor analyst for R.W. Baird, told Investor's Business Daily."(STMicro) has methodically shut down businesses losing money or just breaking even, such as memory chips and cellphone chips," Gerra said. "Now the result is you have a company that is much leaner that only has products that are profitable."STMicro has benefited from relentless smartphone innovations, connected home devices and wearable tech gadgets, as well as emerging opportunities in the automotive and industrial sectors.A massive shift toward greener, safer and self-driving cars is one powerful engine of growth. The industrial Internet of Things — which connects machines to one another and the cloud, while harnessing the power of Big Data analytics to make factories more efficient — is another.STMicro stock has vaulted 125% in the past year. That is more than three times the return of the PHLX SOX Semiconductor Sector Index — dominated by U.S. giants Nvidia (NVDA), Intel (INTC) and Qualcomm (QCOM) — over the same period.Gerra believes STMicro stock has room to run despite the monster moves it already has made, rising to levels not seen in a decade. He has a price target of 20, which represents an upside of roughly 14%. Shares climbed into buy territory Thursday and have kept climbing since then. Shares ended the regular trading session Tuesday up 1.7% to 17.77.STMicro's surging profits and margins come as the firm has raised its capital expenditures to $1.25 billion to $1.3 billion, citing new products and higher demand, while alluding to design wins. Many investors and analysts understand the latter to mean the eagerly awaited 10th anniversary iPhone from Apple (AAPL).STMicro's 3D sensors are expected to power the upcoming iPhone's standout new feature: advanced facial-recognition technologies that may allow users to unlock devices and authenticate payments in a more seamless way, experts say.Improving fundamentals and a robust product portfolio make the stock "well-positioned for a continued recovery with significantly less cyclicality going forward," Gerra said in a recent note, while highlighting the potential for further revenue momentum.Analyst views call for STMicro earnings to more than quadruple to 83 cents a share for fiscal 2017 from 19 cents for 2016, according to Zacks Investment Research. For 2018, that's projected to reach $1.10 a share, then rise to $1.16 in 2019, Zacks says.STMicro holds one of the broadest product portfolios in the chipmaking industry, according to investment research firm Morningstar Inc. And the firm is seeing strong growth in bookings across all its product lines and global regions."We are firing on all cylinders," STMicro Executive Vice President Bob Krysiak told IBD. "We have great pipelines in smartphones, automotives and across the mass-market space."Besides Apple, major customers include Cisco (CSCO), Seagate (STX) and Western Digital (WDC), as well as Asian smartphone makers Huawei and Samsung. Its products end up in everything from cars and smartphones to drones, welding equipment, solar kits, thermostats and consumer electronics.Its micro-mirror MEMS chips in the Amazon (AMZN) Echo Look and near field communication (NFC) chips in the Samsung Galaxy S8 show how the company is innovating and pursuing new lines of growth, according to Gerra. NFC chips allow smart devices to talk to one another when brought physically together, such as pay card readers.The smartphone remains king for the company, notwithstanding slowing sales across the industry."It's a big market that continues to innovate every year," Krysiak said. "Smartphone makers depend on us suppliers to provide the innovation."STMicro has been making strategic moves in this segment. Abandoning its dated Nokia and Blackberry businesses years ago, it switched its focus to phone sensors, power management, security, NFC and other wireless technologies.Its FlightSense technology opens the door to the next generation of proximity sensors. For instance, it helps smartphone cameras focus automatically with much greater accuracy.The biggest opportunities may still be ahead. Smartphones have assumed a role as a central device in the larger Internet of Things, becoming as indispensable to industrial end markets as to the average consumer, Krysiak says.IBD'S TAKE: As IBD Stock Checkup notes, STMicro's stellar ratings for Earnings Per Share growth and Relative Price Strength help it earn a spot among the top five stocks in its industry group.Other massive opportunities are seen in autos and factories. The company has gone well beyond its traditional supplies to the automotive industry.Its positioning and car-to-car communication technologies are making self-driving cars possible. It has partnered with Israeli vision-tech pioneer Mobileye (MBLY) on groundbreaking active safety systems. And with vehicles becoming "almost an internet device," in Krysiak's words, and electrified powertrains on the rise, the silicon content of cars has ballooned.STMicro calls these emerging automotive trends "smart driving" and now averages 36 parts per vehicle produced in the world, up from 24 just a few years ago."Smart driving is just starting," said Krysiak, who believes the opportunity lies not just in intelligent vehicles themselves, but the entire infrastructure — of power charging systems, parking structures and the like — needed to leverage all that processing power.STMicro also is infusing technology into a sector sometimes viewed as boring — industrials.STMicro chips have made data centers more energy efficient, helped robots become more situation-aware and precise, and brought augmented reality and touchless interfaces to industrial assets."The last bastion of change in the digitization of everything will be the factory floor," Krysiak said. "We are bringing our vision systems and processing systems there, all leveraging cloud-computing technologies."STMicro posted net revenue of $6.97 billion in 2016. It spent roughly 19% of that on R&D investments, amid cutthroat industry competition to keep rolling out what the firm describes as "significantly cheaper, smaller, faster, more reliable and embedded" products.For fiscal 2017, STMicro is targeting $8 billion in revenue and is now guiding to the high end of its previous forecast range of 12.5%-15.5% growth.While many analysts regard STMicro as a well-diversified company with some unique products, they see challenges too. Baird's Gerra notes that it remains a somewhat cyclical company, since it has a manufacturing component.Slowing car sales in the U.S. and China — two of the biggest automotive markets — are a potential challenge in the future too.Morningstar analyst Brian Colello also sees risks tied to STMicro's in-house manufacturing, with the need for further research reinvestments and ongoing capital expenditures potentially weighing on profits.He raises yellow flags about other aspects of its operations.There are concerns about STMicro's "ownership by the French and Italian governments, which raises doubts as to whether it is truly focused on operating efficiency," he wrote in a recent report.Finally, STMicro hasn't developed a massive scale advantage given its size, with gross margins and operating profits "below those of other successful pure-play analog chipmakers," Colello said.RELATED:Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksThe New AmericaChip Stocks & Semiconductor Industry News And Analysis

Disk drive manufacturer Western Digital (WDC) reported quarterly results after the market close Thursday that beat on the bottom line and matched estimates on the top.XWestern Digital reported revenue of $4.8 billion, matching consensus estimates and up 37% from the year-ago quarter. It reported adjusted earnings of $2.93, beating views of $2.81, for its fiscal fourth quarter ended June 30.Western Digital stock was near 92.30, up 0.4% in after-market action in the stock market today. Shares of Western Digital are up 34% this year.Shares of rival disk drive company Seagate Technology (STX) fell hard earlier this week after reporting quarterly results that missed expectations. Seagate is the second largest disk drive maker, behind Western Digital.Western Digital said it generated approximately $1 billion in cash from operations during its fiscal fourth quarter, ending with $6.5 billion in cash and equivalents and marketable securities.IBD'S TAKE: Western Digital stock is up 35% this year. The stock has a IBD Composite Rating of 98 out of a possible 99, based on a variety of performance metrics."We operated near the top of our revenue growth model with 7% year-over-year top-line growth on a pro forma basis, and we delivered very healthy margins," said Steve Milligan, Western Digital chief executive, in prepared remarks.Western Digital is engaged in an intense battle with Toshiba over the sale of a chip manufacturing plant that the two jointly run.

The major market indexes sold off in morning trade Wednesday, after a momentary uptick at the starting bell sputtered. All three major indexes — the tech-heavy Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average — declined 0.3%.X Among the Dow industrials, Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) was one of the top performers in the stock market today. The discount chain advanced 0.5% after inking a deal with Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) to link Wal-Mart store accounts to the Google Express shopping service.On the downside, Home Depot (HD) fell 1.5% in sympathy with home improvement competitor Lowe's (LOW), which missed Q2 forecasts early Wednesday. Lowe's fell over 5%, and is consolidating under its 50- and 200-day lines. Shares of Home Depot are building a flat base, but suffered a setback last week amid concerns about slowing growth.Within the S&P 500, hard-drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) declined almost 4%. Rival Western Digital (WDC) advanced over 2% as it attempts to reclaim its 50-day line where it has been trading since July 28.Among companies reporting earnings, Salesforce.com (CRM) reversed from losses to rise 1.7% after the enterprise software provider missed its current-quarter billings guidance. The stock remains in the 5% buy zone from its 92.09 flat-base entry.Meanwhile, American Eagle (AEO) trimmed its gains to 5% early Wednesday after the company reported better-than-expected Q2 earnings results. The retailer has been stuck in a downtrend for about a year. Shares were getting above their 50-day line, but remain stuck under the 200-day line.After the close, home furnishings retailer Williams-Sonoma (WSM) will join HP (HPQ) in reporting their quarterly earnings figures. Williams-Sonoma is stuck in a downtrend, while HP is constructing a cup with handle with a 19.68 buy point.Among leading stocks, PayPal (PYPL) declined over 1%. The payment processor has been one of the top stocks in the stock market and is up almost 10% from a 55.24 flat-base entry.Within the IBD 50, Essent Group (ESNT) moved up almost 2% as it made another attempt to recapture a 39.60 flat-base buy point.On the downside, Autohome (ATHM) fell 1%, but still has an over-80% gain from a 36.11 cup-shaped base.RELATED:Salesforce.com Earnings Beat, But Billings Outlook Below ViewsDow Jones industrial average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisHP, Lowe's, Williams-Sonoma Top Wednesday's Investing Action Plan

Disk-drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) was down hard Tuesday after reporting fiscal fourth-quarter results before the market open that missed expectations.XSeagate reported revenue of $2.4 billion, down 9% from the year-ago quarter and missing the consensus estimate of $2.56 billion. It reported adjusted earnings of 65 cents per share, well below the consensus of 99 cents and down 6%.Seagate rival Western Digital (WDC) reports quarterly results after the market close Thursday. The consensus estimate for Western Digital is adjusted earnings of $2.83, up 258% from the year-ago quarter, and revenue of $4.8 billion, up 37%. Western Digital is the largest provider of disk drives, ahead of Seagate and is also now a formidable player in chip-based flash storage, with its SanDisk acquisitionSeagate stock fell 16.5% to 33.20 on the stock market today. Western Digital stock slipped 0.9% to 93.75.IBD'S TAKE: Seagate has a weak IBD Composite Rating of 62 out of a possible 99, while Western Digital has a strong Composite Rating of 98. Check out the IBD 50 for a screen of leading growth stocks showing strong relative price strength and top-notch fundamentals.Seagate said its board of directors has unanimously voted to appoint Dave Mosley, Seagate's president and chief operating officer, as chief executive effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Seagate CEO Steve Luczo. Mosley was also appointed to Seagate's board of directors, effective July 25."Although the near-term dynamics of technology shifts present demand variations for the storage industry from time to time, we continue to see growing storage demand in the long-run driven by the proliferation of data growth from new technologies, emerging industries, and growing businesses," Luczo said in prepared remarks.Memory-chip maker Micron Technology (MU) fell hard on Tuesday in the wake of earnings reports by Seagate and South Korean memory-chip maker SK Hynix. It was down 5.6% to 29.90. It cut through its 50-day moving average.Also down Tuesday is Everspin Technologies (MRAM), a maker of magnetic RAM chips. Everspin fell as low as 17.12 but closed down just 0.9% to 18.31, but below its 50-day line. Everspin stock has fallen for five of the last six trading sessions after hitting an all-time high of 25.39 on July 18. Chandler, Ariz.-based Everspin went public at 8 last October.RELATED:Western Digital Hits Record High After 'Blowout' Earnings, Outlook

Stocks were divided at the start bell Tuesday as opening gains from Caterpillar (CAT) and McDonald's (MCD) hoisted the Dow, and the Nasdaq was under early pressure from Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) and Seagate Technologies (STX).The Dow Jones industrial average sprung up 0.7% at the open. The S&P 500 futures advanced 0.4%. The Nasdaq composite hung a fraction in the red, despite a strong early gain by Biogen (BIIB).The Federal Open Market Committee today swings into its two-day meeting in Washington, D.C., that will wrap up with a policy announcement Wednesday afternoon. Also in Washington, presidential adviser Jared Kushner faces a second day of closed-door testimony, this time before the House Intelligence Committee, seeking information on possible collusion with Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.Homebuilding stocks were mixed after the Federal Housing Finance Agency reported its Housing Price Index rose 0.4% in May, down from April's 0.6% gain and below economist forecasts for a 0.6% rise. Case/Shiller reported its 20-City Home Price Index gained 5.7% for the month, unchanged from April's growth rate and just a shade below consensus views for a 5.8% advance.Consumer confidence data for July from the Conference Board is due out at 10 a.m. ET.On the Dow, Caterpillar rumbled ahead 5% as its second-quarter results topped expectations. The heavy equipment maker gained more than 1% in powerful trade Monday after BMO Capital Markets upgraded the stock to outperform, from market perform, and hoisted its price target to 125. Shares are extended after a rebound from support at their 10-week moving average.McDonald's grilled up a 4% opening gain, reporting better-than-forecast earnings for the second quarter and a smaller-than-expected decline in revenue. Global comparable sales rose 6.6%, vs. views near 4%. THe gain left the stock at the top if its buy range in its first test of 10-week support since clearing a cup-with-handle base in February.United Technologies (UTX) slipped 2%, despite second-quarter earnings and revenue topped consensus estimates. The aircraft engine and components maker has been trading tightly along its 10-week line of support, and is extended after clearing a flat base in April.3M (MMM) tumbled 4% lower as earnings and revenue growth stopped short of consensus estimates. The maker of adhesives, medical and industrial products is trading 6% below a 214.67 buy point in a five-week flat base.The Nasdaq took an early hit from Alphabet, which slumped 3% after reporting late Monday its second-quarter results that were better than expected, but also missing a $2.7 billion bite due to fines paid to European Union regulators. Alphabet is in the eighth week of a flat base with buy points at 994.09 and 1008.71.Also on the Nasdaq, Seagate Technologies unraveled 19% after scoring broad fourth-quarter sales and earnings misses, and announcing a shakeup in top management.  The hard disk drive and solid state storage device maker's earnings were 34% below analyst targets and revenue declined a wider-than-expected 9%. The company announced Chief Executive Steve Luczo will take the chairman's seat Oct. 1, and be replaced by President and Chief Operating Officer Dave Mosley. Seagate shares had turned in a 178% advance in the 11 months to April, but have dropped off 37% from their April high.Seagate peer Western Digital (WDC) saw some sympathy selling, falling 3% in early action despite Loop Capital initiating coverage on the stock with a buy rating late Monday.Biogen climbed 1% after second-quarter revenue and earnings cleared expectations by wide margins, and management raised its full-year earnings guidance to above consensus estimates. Biogen shares have been rangebound, unable to break above the 312 price level, for the past 11 months.Electronics contract manufacturer Sanmina (SANM) dived 14% on third-quarter revenue growth that fell short of analyst targets, and fourth-quarter earnings guidance at the low end of consensus views.  Tuesday's loss sent shares below their 10-week moving average in heavy trade, triggering a sell signal.In non-earnings news, Medicines Co. (MDCO) spiked 5% after reporting positive interim results from a clinical trial of its meropenem-vaborbactam, a treatment for carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae.  The stock remains in a three-month, 30%-deep consolidation.

Michael Kors (KORS) fell 3% after agreeing to acquire luxury shoe brand Jimmy Choo for $1.2 billion. Hopes for wireless industry consolidation, perhaps through the merger of T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Sprint (S), have dimmed.RELATED:Senators Come Out Against AT&T-Time Warner Deal, While Trump MumAT&T Q1 Sales Miss, Carrier To Halt Revenue GuidanceStifel upgraded the social media firm to buy from neutral with a price target of 22. Investors may be over-reacting to the IPO lock-up expiration, says analyst Scott Devitt, who said the stock's decline creates a "compelling" risk-reward opportunity."At least 950 million additional SNAP shares will become available for sale in the next month; however, with shares recently breaking IPO price ($17), we think investors' anticipation of the event could be more impactful to the stock than actual selling from the lock-up expiration," he said in a report.Shares in Snap were up about 3% to 15.69. The stock slid 1.5% to 15.24 on Wednesday, hitting an all-time low of 15.21 intraday. Snap crashed nearly 9% on Tuesday after lead underwriter Morgan Stanley downgraded the Snapchat parent. On Monday, Snap stock dropped below its March IPO price.RELATED:Here Are The 4 Challenges That Snap Is Failing To OvercomeBarclays downgraded the data storage company to underweight. Shares in Seagate, a rival of Western Digital (WD), fell 3.5% to 38.32.RELATED:Western Digital Hits Record High After 'Blowout' Earnings, OutlookJPMorgan hiked enterprise software provider Workday's (WDAY) price target to 115 from 105. Shares in the maker of human resources and financial management software rose 1% to 104 early Thursday. Workday stock has shot up 56% in 2017 and is extended, trading above a 92.56 buy point.RELATED:Workday Profit Blows Past Estimates, Revenue Beats, But Shares SlipIn other analyst moves, Oppenheimer raised RingCentral (RNG) price target to 45 from 33. A busy day of headlines Tuesday resulted in a nice day of outperformance for the Dow Jones industrial average and a new high for the S&P 500 but a sluggish day overall for tech stocks.Alphabet (GOOGL) cast a pall on the tech sector after the company reported earnings late Monday. Shares fell 3%.At the close, the Dow rose almost 0.5%; the S&P 500 added 0.3% and the Nasdaq composite rose less than 0.1%. Small caps fared the best with the Russell 2000 up 0.8%. Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq both coming in higher than Monday's levels.X Inside the Dow, Caterpillar (CAT) soared 6% on a nice earnings beat and second straight quarter of accelerating sales growth. McDonald's (MCD), meanwhile, jumped 5% as Wall Street cheered solid earnings as well as a 3.9% increase in U.S. same-store sales, nicely above expectations.Financials also outperformed as bond yields rose. Dow components JPMorgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) ended with gains of nearly 2%. JPMorgan is back near highs but just below a 94.08 buy point. Goldman has been a laggard in the financial sector for a while now as it trades near  its recently converged 50- and 200-day moving averages.The yield on the 10-year Treasury note was up 7 basis points  to 2.32% as the two-day Fed meeting got underway. A decision on interest rates is due Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET.The market is not expecting a rate hike tomorrow, and one more before the end of the year is still in question, according to the CME Group FedWatch tool. Futures traders think there's a 47% chance the Fed will hike rates one more time before the end of the year.Some oil and gas-related groups outperformed as oil prices jumped. September WTI crude oil jumped $1.55, or 3.3%, to settle at $47.89 a barrel.Heavy-volume gainers included Rio Tinto (RIO). Shares jumped 5% to 45.93. It's still in buy range after gapping up over a 45.81 cup-with-handle buy point. Mining firms outperformed on the heels of strong results from Freeport-McMoRan (FCX), which soared nearly 15%.On the downside, shares of Seagate (STX) crashed more than 16% on a big earnings miss. It's been a laggard since gapping below the 50-day moving in late April. Domino's Pizza (DPZ) was another big loser, down 10%, despite another quarter of strong bottom-line and top-line growth. U.S. same-store sales in the quarter rose 9.5%.RELATED:McDonald's Touts Digital Progress; Domino's Falls HardWhy The Federal Reserve Might Spring A Surprise Wednesday; Bank Stocks RallyApple Analysts Brace For 'Big Guide Down' Amid iPhone 8 Delay Reports

The major market indexes traded mixed in early trading Monday. The Dow Jones industrial average led the way, rising 0.3%, as a slew of earnings beats buoyed the blue-chip index. The S&P 500 gained 0.3% to touch another record high, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq edged slightly lower.XAmong the Dow industrials, McDonald's (MCD) and Caterpillar (CAT) were the day's best performers, advancing about 4% each. The Golden Arches beat earnings and sales estimates as its new line of premium sandwiches helped boost same-store sales in the U.S. by 3.9%. Global same-stores sales increase 6.6% in Q2. Shares of the restaurant chain operator offered a brief buy opportunity on a rebound from support at their 10-week moving average.Meanwhile, Caterpillar beat the Street's Q2 forecasts, while boosting its full-year revenue and profit outlook. Shares found support at their 50-day line last Friday and are now 13% above a 99.56 flat-base entry.On the downside, MMM (MMM) plunged nearly 6% to break through its 50-day line in heavy volume after Q2 revenues came in lower than expected.Energy names were some of the top performing stocks in the stock market today as the price of crude oil increased over 2%. Transocean (RIG) and Murphy Oil (MUR) jumped over 3% apiece, but remain stuck in long-term downtrends under their 200-day lines.FANG member Alphabet (GOOGL) declined almost 3% despite beating its Q2 earnings estimates late Monday. Investors were concerned about the company's traffic acquisition costs, which rose 28% in Q2. Shares approached their 1008.72 flat-base entry on Monday, but never broke out. The stock will need to set up to try again after today's decline.Among leading stocks, data storage leaders Western Digital (WDC) and Micron Technology (MU) declined 1.3% and 4.3%, respectively, after Seagate Technology (STX) missed Q4 earnings targets early Tuesday. Shares of Seagate plunged 15% and the stock was trading at a new 2017 low.Meanwhile, Western Digital and Micron found themselves back near their 50-day lines. Western Digital is still holding well-above its 79.25 double-bottom buy point. Micron is just above its 29.97 flat-base entry.Within the IBD 50, Centene Corp (CNC) jumped 1% and is approaching the 20% profit-taking level from a 73.33 cup-with-handle entry.On the downside, China-based New Oriental Education (EDU) declined 3% as it builds the right side of a potential base. The stock may be adding a handle to its cup base, but volume has been heavy when it should be light — a negative sign.RELATED:Google Q2 Earnings Beat But Traffic Costs Jump, Apple To Blame?Seagate Technology Shares Crater On Earnings ShortfallDow Jones industrial average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisFANG Stocks News & Quotes: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google

Stocks rumbled to a solid finish Friday in a week that left two of the three major indexes at fresh highs and the other with its strongest performance of the year.The Nasdaq seized a 0.6% gain, with NetApp (NTAP) and Seagate Technology (STX) leading the Nasdaq 100. Apple (AAPL) rose 0.9% to end flush with its 50-day moving average.The S&P 500 clocked a 0.5% advance, while the Dow Jones industrial average steered 0.4% higher.For the week, the Nasdaq nailed a 2.6% advance to lodge its best week since early December, and ending within three points of its June 9 high. The S&P 500 climbed 1.4%, moving to a new high, while the Dow industrials swung up 1% to ace another fresh high.Among the Dow's stocks Microsoft (MSFT) and Wal-Mart (WMT) duked it out for the top slot. Microsoft closed just below a 72.99 buy point after rising as high as 73.27 intraday in average volume from a flat base. Wal-Mart's fourth-straight advance positioned it for a test of resistance at its 50-day moving average.Among IBD 50 stocks, China's YY Inc. (YY) was the highflier, up 9% in big trade. That left shares still in buy range above two alternative buy points in a flat base, an aggressive one at 60.94 and a regular one at 61.62.NetApp led a rebound among data storage names, surging 5.5% in weighty trade to break out past a 43.24 buy point and nail a new high. Other names in the group include Seagate Technology, which popped 3% in mild trade.Retail and banking groups posted nearly all of Friday's worst losses among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. High-end names like RH (RH) and Williams-Sonoma (WSM) led the declines in the worst-hit home furnishings retail group. Group 1 (GPI) and Penske Automotive (PAG) paced the downside among the session's hard-hit auto dealerships.Big banks including JPMorgan (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) sharply trimmed their early losses after reporting quarter results, but the selling had already spread to the superregional and regional banking groups. A softer than expected rise in core consumer prices for June further eased pressure on the Fed to press for the additional rate hikes that are already valued into many banking stocks.Gold miners and solar energy plays were Friday's top advancers among industries.China receives official estimates for second-quarter GDP as well as June industrial production and retail sales late Sunday, which could affect U.S. trade to start the week. Netflix (NFLX) reports its second-quarter results after Monday's close.RELATED:Netflix, Microsoft, GE To Amp Up Earnings: Investing Action Plan Move Over FANGs, China BATs Go From Copycats To Fat CatsWhich 7 Chinese Stocks Are Fund Managers Buying?

In a very busy week for news, stocks rallied solidly. Markets worldwide cheered the results of the first round of France's presidential election. Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOGL) and Dow stock McDonald's (MCD) hit record highs on earnings, while Intel (INTC) and Starbucks (SBUX) tumbled, with hundreds of other companies reporting. President Trump's big tax-cut plan, which had lifted markets in anticipation, didn't move the needle when its outline was finally released.The major market averages jumped Monday and Tuesday after Emmanuel Macron led the first round of voting in the French presidential election, with polls suggesting he will easily defeat nationalist Marine Le Pen in the early May runoff. Stocks largely consolidated gains the rest of the week, though individual stocks and sectors were active amid a flurry of earnings. Internet, chips, restaurants and casinos were leaders, while Baidu (BIDU), Intel and Starbucks showed that even leading groups had losers. But the Nasdaq composite hit record highs during the week, climbing 2.3%. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.9%, while the S&P 500 index was up 1.5%, just below all-time bests.The e-commerce giant said adjusted income rose 38% year over year to $1.48 a share, beating the consensus Q1 estimate of $1.12. Revenue rose 23% to $35.7 billion, topping views of $35.3 billion. That maintained a steady streak of double-digit revenue gains going back more than four years.Amazon Web Services, Amazon's cloud computing unit, continued to deliver huge, if gradually slowing, growth.Amazon shares rose to a record high Friday, clearing a new buy point, but closing well off intraday peaks.The earnings of Google-parent Alphabet rose 28% as revenue rose 22%, to $24.75 billion. Analysts expected the company to report earnings of $7.40 a share on sales of $24.22 billion. Revenue at Google's "other" non-advertising business — which includes its cloud computing unit, Pixel smartphones and the Play store — rose 49%, to $3.01 billion. Mobile advertising growth was a bright spot, although Google's rising traffic-acquisition costs are a concern. TAC refers to what Google pays partner websites to carry ads, or what it pays partners like Apple (AAPL) that generate search traffic. Alphabet shares gapped up 3.8% to a fresh record high Friday.McDonald's first-quarter results beat views, and the burger giant talked up its tech efforts, including expanding delivery, trying out mobile order and pay and its new digitized restaurant layout. Shares jumped to record highs. Domino's Pizza (DPZ) also beat and said it was testing GPS-tracking technology. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) beat as well, and analysts debated its progress following a food-borne illness scare. Starbucks matched profit expectations, but missed on sales amid worries about stalling growth. Starbucks shares undercut a recent buy point intraday Friday, but closed above that level.Software leader Microsoft (MSFT) delivered earnings per share above views for its fiscal third quarter, but sales came in a tad short. Its sales guidance for the June quarter also was below analyst estimates. Microsoft earned 73 cents a share excluding items, up 18% year over year, on adjusted revenue of $23.56 billion, up 6%, in the March quarter. Analysts expected 70 cents and $23.62 billion. For the current quarter, Microsoft guided to sales of $24.15 billion, up 7%, but Wall Street had been modeling for $24.51 billion.Intel earnings topped, but the chip giant's sales fell shy amid weakness in its data center market, sending shares gapping down 3.5% Friday. Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI), Mellanox Technologies (MLNX), KLA-Tencor (KLAC) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) were chip plays that retreated. But Cavium (CAVM) and Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) rallied after the chipmakers topped Q1 earnings. Gear makers Teradyne (TER) and Ultra Clean (UCTT) boomed on results.Lockheed Martin (LMT) sees more international demand for its F-35 fighter and missile-defense systems as global tensions heat up and Raytheon (RTN) sees "significant demand signals" for its munitions on increasing military operations in Syria. Lockheed's Q1 sales fell short of expectations and it gave weak guidance. Northrop Grumman (NOC) and General Dynamics (GD) topped on EPS and sales. All four defense stocks were in buy range at some point in the week, but by Friday's close all were slightly below entry areas.Core Boeing (BA) earnings jumped 16% to $2.01, beating views, but revenue fell 7% as defense revenue fell 18%. Free cash flow soared to $1.63 billion from $527 million. The aerospace giant raised its full year EPS outlook, but the midpoint still fell below analyst views. Industrial conglomerate United Technologies (UTX) topped with slim EPS and sales gains, as Otis elevator revenue, aerospace system sales and Pratt & Whitney jet engine sales rose.Boeing shares rose toward a flat-base buy point. United Tech is at a 23-month high, at the edge of buying range.Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate Technology (STX), the two largest providers of disk drives, had differing earnings. Seagate revenue missed estimates, with the stock falling 17% in reaction. Western Digital's earnings beat on the top and bottom lines, and announced very bullish guidance, sending shares up 3.9% Friday.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) pulled ahead of forecasts with 99 cents EPS and $1.475 billion in sales, as Macau gaming activity continues to rebound. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) EPS rose 47% to 66 cents, topping, on 15% revenue growth, meeting views. MGM Resorts (MGM) topped handily on both the top and bottom lines, helped by the takeover of the Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa and the MGM National Harbor opening. Wynn Resorts hit a two-year high, and MGM rose to its best since 2008, with shares in buy range. Sands advanced within a consolidation.Exxon Mobil (XOM) reported mixed first-quarter results but said it had no plans to adjust its capital expenditure guidance as the oil major has identified and captured capital efficiencies. Exxon warned that it still needed to be cautious on the rebalancing of the oil market. Chevron (CVX) swung to a profit in Q1 and revenue beat Wall Street estimates as overall production rose. Management said if oil remains around $50 a barrel then future spending would be near the low end of its capex forecast. U.S. oil prices are modestly below $50 a barrel as Baker Hughes announced the U.S. oil rigs in operation rose for a 15th straight week, foreshadowing further production gains.T-Mobile US (TMUS) topped Q1 earnings estimates and continued its streak of grabbing the most new subscribers among wireless operators. T-Mobile added 798,000 postpaid phone subscribers vs. 877,000 in the year-earlier period; that topped estimates of 725,000. T-Mobile shares rose to a new high, in buy range. AT&T (T) is expected to ramp up advertising for bundled wireless and pay TV offers after reporting in-line EPS and revenue that fell more than expected. AT&T lost 348,000 wireless postpaid subscribers, more than expected. Subscriber growth at DirecTV Now's streaming service helped AT&T offset surprising weakness at DirecTV's traditional pay TV business. But AT&T shares fell to 2017 low.Separately, cable giant Comcast (CMCSA) rose to a new high on strength in its movie business and broadband-customer gains.Recall costs and slowing U.S. sales hurt Ford (F) earnings, which fell but still beat Q1 views. Ford said higher commodity costs, particularly in steel, could weigh but that the worst hit to profit and costs this year likely happened in Q1. General Motors (GM) beat forecasts on solid U.S. truck and crossover sales, while Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) held its full-year outlook and kept its debt in check. The results come amid concerns about slowing auto sales, rising inventories and falling used-car prices.Dow Jones industrial average equipment-maker Caterpillar (CAT) earned $1.28 a share in Q1, more than doubling estimates, and raised its 2017 revenue range by $2 billion to $39-$41 billion, vs. estimates of $38.3 billion. Caterpillar's good news comes despite lack of progress on President Trump's infrastructure program or border wall, two initiatives that have made Caterpillar a Trump stock. Ahead of earnings, Caterpillar finally broke a 51-month streak of falling retail sales, with a 1% gain that was driven by construction equipment sales in the Asia-Pacific region. Caterpillar shares soared into a buy zone.Biotechs and drugmakers reported en masse Thursday with AbbVie (ABBV), Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) and Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) delivering across-the-board beats, pumping their stocks up that day. AstraZeneca (AZN) topped on earnings, but sales slid 12%, though adjusted profits grew 4% and topped by 17 cents. Top two biotechs, Amgen (AMGN) and Celgene (CELG), both reported lagging sales. On Thursday, Acorda Therapeutics (ACOR) stock hit an 11-year low on light sales and an 8-cent per-share loss ex items that also missed.Even as the House made another push to repeal ObamaCare — with a plan that included steep cuts for Medicaid — a raft of insurers moved into buy zones, and flirted with breakouts or pushing to new highs. The catalyst was an especially strong earnings report from Anthem (ANTM), though investors may have judged that TrumpCare remains doomed. Humana (HUM) previewed its earnings and raised guidance. Centene (CNC) topped estimates and CEO Michael Neidorff said he expects the Medicaid-heavy insurer to thrive on any reform that can be passed by Congress, noting that "20 Republican senators come from states that expanded Medicaid."PulteGroup (PHM) topped earnings estimates, but revenue fell short. Meanwhile, President Trump imposed a 20% tariff on Canadian softwood imports, which could raise construction costs by $1,200 per home. New-home sales rose in March to the second-fastest rate of the current business cycle. Pulte tumbled, but did not outright close below a prior buy point. D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) fell below their 50-day lines as well.

Stocks opened flat Wednesday after logging two days of powerful gains.The Dow Jones industrial average, Nasdaq and S&P 500 were up less than 0.1%.The Dow Jones industrial average rolled into Wednesday's session up 2.2% since Monday morning and trading less than 1% below its March 1 high. Cree (CREE) and Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI) dropped 10% and 8%, respectively, following their quarterly reports. The stock closed Monday just below its April 3 high, and extended after clearing a flat base in mid-March.On the downside, U.S. Steel (X) tanked 24.5% after reporting a surprise loss of 83 cents a share vs. expectations for a 35-cent per-share profit. The market uptrend, for now, remains under pressure with five distribution days marked over the past 25 sessions for the 500.U.S. government bonds, meanwhile, edged lower and the 10-year Treasury yield rose to nearly 2.42%, according to Tradeweb, following a slight upward adjustment to the Q4 growth in U.S. GDP to 2.1% vs. a prior revised print of 1.9%. Plus, the stock had broken out after it had rallied back above the 50- and 200-day moving averages.However. it would have been totally understandable to have passed on this breakout attempt. While 54.94 was sharply higher than the recent low of 34.99, Western still down sharply off its then 52-week high of 86.39. There's no shortage of star power in First Trust Nasdaq-100-Technology Sector ETF (QTEC), with Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB), Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet (GOOGL) among its holdings.Indeed, the exchange traded fund is a way to gain exposure to the biggest brands in technology, and those stocks are performing well. Because it's culled from the Nasdaq 100 (the largest nonfinancial stocks in the composite), the ETF is predominantly a big-cap fund, with a median market cap of $32 billion.More than 40% of the fund is in chip stocks. About one-fourth is in software, 17% in internet companies and the rest in hardware, services and telecom stocks. The fund's hardware stocks have been shining.Western Digital (WDC) has surged more than 130% from a low in May 2016. The data storage stock broke out of a base March 30 and remains near a 81.77 buy point. Rival Seagate Technology (STX) has risen more than 160% from its May low. Apple may be flagging the past couple of weeks, but shares have rallied about 20% from a breakout past a 118.12 entry in January.The internet components haven't exactly impressed. Alphabet — the parent company of Google — Yahoo (YHOO), Baidu (BIDU), Akamai (AKAM) and NetEase (NTES) have printed mediocre charts for months. Facebook, though, is still trending moderately upward.Despite relative strength in the sector, the ETF's semiconductor stocks have been mixed.What about the sector's outlook? Much depends on consumer reception to new products, such as the next iPhone model, and corporate spending on information technology. Earlier this month, Nomura analysts saw strength in that area."Our early-April survey of 50 global CIOs offered a significantly improved view of 2017 IT spending vs. our October survey," the firm noted. "This suggests the economic and financial upticks since October may prove resilient. The top spending drivers, security and cloud, remain key themes."The tech sector is turning in the third-highest earnings growth rate of 11 S&P sectors at 13.0%, according to FactSet.The 35 companies in the ETF are about evenly distributed in terms of weighting, each accounting for 1.5% to 3.2% of the portfolio. That leaves the fund less exposed to risk from a single holding.The ETF has made an impressive run since it broke out of a long consolidation and started making new highs last July. Today, shares are finding support at the 50-day moving average. That leaves investors with an opportunity to buy shares, although it needs to be treated as a secondary entry, not as favorable as a base breakout. Micron Technology (MU) got an upgrade Tuesday, and several analysts lauded the potential benefits of joint ventures the memory chipmaker discussed during its annual analyst day on Friday.

The Boise, Idaho-based company discussed a renegotiated supply agreement with Inotera that should result in "significant benefit," and a new partnership announced Thursday with Seagate Technology (STX), Pacific Crest Securities analyst Monika Garg said in a research report Tuesday.

"The new Inotera agreement could lead to 8% to 10% higher DRAM (dynamic random-access memory) margins from Inotera," Garg said. "Our analysis suggests this could lead to 300 to 380 basis points of higher DRAM margins in 2016 and 32 cents to 40 cents to our 2016 earnings per share estimates."
Besides DRAMs, the most used PC memory, Micron makes Nand flash-memory chips used in smartphones, tablets and digital cameras.

Macquarie analyst Deepen Nag raised his rating on Micron Technology to outperform from neutral in a Tuesday research report. He wrote that Micron's statements about margins going up by eight to 10 points and capital spending returning to normal patterns "provide potential significant incremental upside to free cash flow estimates."
Micron Technology stock was up 2% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 32.50.

Summit Research Partners analyst Srini Sundararajan said in a research note Tuesday that the deal with Seagate enables the disk drive company to share its SAS (Serial Attached SCSI) solid-state drive technology with Micron, which will share its flash-memory supply with Seagate.
SAS technology enables multiple devices of different sizes and types to be connected simultaneously with thinner and longer cables, among other features.

Micron announced Feb. 10 that it had renegotiated a supply agreement with Inotera in which the price for DRAM products sold to Micron will be based on a formula that equally shares margin between the companies, taking into account each company's manufacturing costs and Micron's operating expense ratio.

Sundararajan said the two-year deal, which also includes options to extend the pact longer, "will likely bring Micron Technology's margin at least to the high 40s by itself" and will be above 50% once other costs savings are factored in.

Benchmark analyst Gary Mobley said in a research note Tuesday that while the agreement between Micron and Seagate initially focuses on next-generation SAS solid-state drives and strategic Nand supply, "the two companies anticipate the multiyear agreement will extend into future collaborations.

"The framework of the agreement will enable customers of the two companies to benefit from a focused approach to deliver industry-leading storage solutions, helping them innovate faster and more effectively."

XBargain hunters moved into the market and the Dow Jones industrial average looked poised to recoup all early losses on Monday afternoon, helping shave some of the indexes' losses with an hour to go in the session. However, the S&P 500 looks poised to register its seventh distribution day, or session of intense professional selling, in recent weeks.The S&P 500, off by as much as 0.8% by around 12:05 p.m. ET, likely skirted a distribution day with a loss of less than 0.2%. Meanwhile, the S&P 100, which tracks the 100 largest companies monitored by Standard & Poor's, nearly closed breakeven, down less than 1 point.The Dow Jones industrial average also cutt its losses, down less than 0.1%. The Nasdaq composite dropped around 0.3%. Volume appeared to finish higher on the Nasdaq vs. the same time on Friday.The relatively high distribution count is offset by the fact that most of the distribution days going back over the prior 25 sessions were light in nature. Plus, the major benchmarks are holding close to all-time highs. Nonetheless, equities have had a superb run since late June, and for now the current uptrend remains at "uptrend under pressure."Read IBD's The Big Picture column on a daily basis to monitor important changes in the overall market direction. The last time IBD set the outlook at "market in correction" came on June 27 last year.Meanwhile, while the tech sector remains hot, a few leaders are showing some selling stress.Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI), a big winner since the start of the year, fell 3% to 54.42. It recently formed  a faulty V-shaped cup base that fell way short of the minimum six weeks needed to form a good pattern. The two-weeks-down/two-weeks-up action has been seen in many past winners, based on IBD's research of sell signals among the top market leaders.Applied made a stunning run after clearing a 27.38 buy point in a seven-week base in mid-January. In less than nine weeks, the maker of laser components and subassemblies for fiber optic networks ran up more than 100% to a high of 56.14. The two-week pullback that followed put the finishing touches on a rare high, tight flag pattern. However, one critical flaw in Applied's flag was the unusually heavy volume during the two down weeks that produced the flag portion.Nevertheless, those who bought at the 27.38 proper entry and have conviction in the company can sit tight for now. Shares are still well above the fast-rising 10-week moving average.The Street sees Applied Optoelectronics' earnings rising 144% to $3.39 a share this year on a 46% vault in revenue to $380 million.The company's revenue rose 24%, 66%, 46% and 37% in the prior four years through 2016.Cognex (CGNX) hit a new high of 86.88, but reversed for a mild loss of nearly 0.3%. Volume is huge. More negative price reversals in fast turnover would mean it's time to lock in at least partial profits.Seagate Technology (STX) fell nearly 2% to 45.08 in rising turnover vs. Friday. The data storage giant is trying to cling to its rising 50-day moving average after a nearly 20% gain from a breakout past 41.55.A solid bounce off the 50-day line would greatly benefit current Seagate holders. Otherwise, taking at least partial profits in the mid-cap tech firm makes good sense from a portfolio management perspective.Taking profits at 20% to 25% in numerous companies not only builds up an overall nice return, but the disciplined selling also frees up cash for an investor to potentially find an even better market leader.Use IBD's Stocks On The Move table, found in the "Stocks List" section at Investors.com, to find high-quality stocks rising in huge volume, then analyze their fundamentals and level of mutual fund and hedge fund sponsorship quickly via IBD Stock Checkup. Consultant Science Applications International (SAIC) continues to struggle, falling nearly 2% to 73.08 and clipping its 200-day line, just two days after it cratered more than 13% on Thursday and took out its 50-day moving average in monster volume.SAI on Thursday posted a 7% rise in fiscal fourth-quarter earnings to 95 cents a share, extending a four-quarter streak of gains, but it was the smallest year-over-year increase over that time frame. Revenue sank 4% to $1.03 billion, accelerating a 2% decline in the third quarter that ended in October.Marvell Technology (MRVL) is losing vital support at the 50-day line. It had recently broken out of a flat base with a 15.09 entry. Shares in the former Leaderboard member slipped 1.5% to 15.03, thus round-tripping a mild double-digit gain.Also in the stock market today, Snap (SNAP) slipped nearly 1% to 22.31, but volume appears on track to be one of the lightest sessions since the stock's IPO on March 2.Notice on a weekly chart how the Snapchat site's operator showed a tight weekly close last week. It fell nearly 1% to 22.53 and action was wild during the week, but the minor weekly price change represents a clue that institutions are holding firmly, not anxious to sell.Enterprise software firm MuleSoft (MULE), a March 17 IPO at 17 a share, is staging another sharp gain, rising nearly 4% to 25.20 and approaching a 26.02 buy point in a very narrow potential IPO base. It pared earlier gains to a little more than 1%. IPO bases contain much more risk because they often form over a much shorter period of time.After peaking at 25.92 on March 19, MuleSoft dropped 16% to as low as 21.80 in just six sessions. However, a 16% correction from high to low is not extreme. At 24.34, the stock is also up 43% from its IPO pricing, indicating that institutional demand is robust.Keep in mind that IBD ratings for brand new stocks are skewed by the fact that they have not traded long enough. For instance, the Relative Price Strength Rating is based on action over the past 12 months, with a higher weighting on three-month action. MuleSoft is just starting Week 4 of its life in the public stock markets. Goldman Sachs helped bring the company public.MuleSoft has no earnings despite growing its revenue by 70% to $188 million last year.RELATED:Stock Market Today: I: Can These 6 Leaders Become The Next Cisco Of The 2010s?Stock Market Today II: Is It Time To Sell These 11 Leading Names?Great Stocks For Income Investors: Can These 3 Financial Plays Rally Big In 2017?

Analyst actions on Tuesday included upgrades for Yelp (YELP),  Seagate Technology (STX) and Western Digital (WDC), while Swift Transportation (SWFT) was downgraded, and United Continental (UAL) got a price-target hike.Pacific Crest upgraded the online customer-review site to overweight from sector weight with a 43 price target. Analyst Brad Erickson said checks with local ad customers confirm that Yelp's market position is solid and he says it's in a good position to benefit as $60 billion of local ad spending increasingly moves online.But on Monday, Roth Capital reiterated a sell rating and 27.50 target for Yelp, citing competition from big tech companies such as Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and Facebook (FB) in directing mobile, location-based connectivity between consumers and local businesses.Shares of Yelp rose 1.9% to 33.37 on the stock market today.RELATED:Yelp Q4 Mostly In Line, Revenue Outlook Light, Stock FallsYelp's Brand Recognition Has Risen Considerably, Survey ShowsCowen & Co. raised its price target on the airline to 75 from 72, keeping a market perform rating. The stock broke out of a base on March 30 and continues to push higher.The tech unicorn IPO, which popped 45% on its first day of trading, got new coverage from a host of analysts. Jefferies gave the enterprise-software developer a buy rating and 27 target. Canaccord Genuity gave MuleSoft (MULE) a hold rating and 24 target.Shares sank 4.3% to 22.30, a record closing low after nearly setting a record post-IPO intraday low.Deutsche Bank upgraded Knight Transportation (KNX) to buy from hold, hiking its target price to 40 from 33 after its agreement to acquire Swift Transportation.But Raymond James downgraded Swift to market perform from outperform. Stocks opened lower Tuesday, as commodities were generally quiet and overseas markets booked mixed sessions.The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite lost 0.3%.Walt Disney (DIS) jumped 1%. Disney's live-action fairy tale "Beauty & the Beast" took second place at the box office over the weekend, earning $25 million domestically over the three days, and bringing its four-week global take to nearly $1 billion. Disney shares have been trading tightly and above the 10-week moving average.Another Dow component, McDonald's (MCD), popped 0.6% at the open. The burger chain's stock is trying to clear a 130.10 buy point.Elsewhere, RetailMeNot (SALE) soared 49%. The online coupon aggregator announced late Monday it would be taken private by MacAndrews & Forbes for $11.60 a share, 50% above Monday's closing price. The company valued the deal at $630 million. United shares on Monday were testing resistance at their 10-week moving average, trying to climb the right side of a base.At the head of both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq 100, Western Digital (WDC) swung up nearly 3% on an upgrade to overweight from neutral by JPMorgan, which gave a new 116 price target. Western Digital shares were nearing the top of a buy range after clearing a flat base buy point of 81.77 in heavy trade on March 30. Data storage peer Seagate Technology (STX) rose 3%.Qualcomm (QCOM) dropped nearly 2% and Apple (AAPL) dipped 0.1% on reports that Qualcomm late Monday filed counter-claims against Apple, alleging the larger company of a series of unethical practices. Qualcomm has been consolidating since October.The Labor Department's Job Openings And Labor Turnover Survey — the JOLTS report — for February is due out at 10 a.m. ET. Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari speaks at 1:45 p.m. ET.Oil traded flat, gold rose 0.5% to above $1,260 an ounce. The dollar sifted lower and bonds rose, sending the 10-year yield down 3 basis points to 2.33%.In Europe, benchmark indexes in Paris and Frankfurt remained mixed in afternoon trade, while the FTSE 100 in London rose 0.7%. China's leading benchmarks booked a mixed session, with the Shanghai Composite ending up 0.6% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng down 0.7%. Companies in the S&P 500 paid a record $376 billion in dividends over the trailing 12-month period ended in January, according to an analyst report from FactSet. Apple (AAPL) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) topped all other components paying out more than $11 billion each.

The tech giant's large dollar payout doesn't translate to a high yield, however. At 1.5%, Apple's yield is below the S&P 500 trailing 12-month yield of 1.9%. Its stock, meanwhile, is bouncing back from a recent trip to the 10-week line and is only about 4% off an all-time high.
Other top payers came from varied industries including AT&T (T), Microsoft (MSFT), General Electric (GE) and Wells Fargo (WFC).
Wells Fargo's stock is in buy range past a 55.66 cup-with-handle buy point. It has a dividend yield of 2.5%.
Over the trailing 12 months, 421 stocks, or 84% of the S&P 500, paid a dividend. Dividends per share increased 11.9% on the index with 341 companies raising their payouts.
Analysts see dividend growth on the index slowing over the next 12 months to 8.2%.

Companies that increased their dividends the most in the last year, with at least a 2% yield, largely hailed from the financial and energy sectors. Large-cap insurers Progressive (PGR) and Principal Financial Group (PFG) each stepped up their payouts by more than 30%. Energy plays Transocean (RIG), Noble (NE) and Oneok (OKE) also had healthy hikes, led by Oneok's 53% increase.
Noble currently has the highest yield in the S&P 500 at 11.1%. Its shares though, have been in a sharp downtrend for more than a year and are about 50% off its 52-week high.
Disk drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) has the best 5-year dividend growth rate at 44%.

Shares of disk drive makers Seagate Technology (STX) and Western Digital tumbled Monday after Seagate posted earnings and gave guidance below Wall Street consensus.
Seagate reported earnings per share minus items of $1.35, up 2% from the year-earlier quarter and in line with guidance, for its fiscal second quarter ended Jan. 2.
Revenue rose 5% to $3.7 billion, just shy of consensus estimate of $3.74 billion.
Weak sales in Europe and weak disk drive prices hurt, analysts said. Europe accounts for about 20% of company revenue.

Seagate stock was down 9%, at a three-month low near 58, in early afternoon trading on the stock market today. Shares of top rival Western Digital (WDC) were down 6%, near 100. Western Digital is set to report its fiscal Q2 earnings after the market close Tuesday.
Before Monday, Seagate stock was up 14% this year and Western Digital stock was up 26%.
Shebly Seyrafi, analyst at FBN Securities, maintained a sector perform rating on Seagate but lowered his price target to 60 from 65.

"Europe normally would have been up about 5% in the December quarter, but instead was down 5%," Seyrafi wrote. "Some supply constraints exist in the cloud market as well, and this supply challenge is expected to last a few quarters."
The average selling price for hard drives was $61, up $1 from the previous quarter but down $1 from the year-earlier quarter.
Seagate projected fiscal Q3 revenue of about $3.45 billion, down 1.5% from the year-earlier quarter and below consensus of $3.58 billion.
Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter @IBD_BDeagon.
